t: Exodus 15
The Song of Moses and Miriam
Then*p Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the Lord:*s “I*pn will sing to the Lord,*s for*ld he is highly exalted. Both*ln horse and driver he*ld has hurled into the sea.
“The*pn Lord*s is my strength and my defense; he*ld has become my salvation. He*ln is my God, and I will praise him, my*ld father’s God, and I will exalt him.
The*ln Lord*s is a warrior; the*ld Lord*s is his name.
Pharaoh’s*ln chariots and his army he*ld has hurled into the sea. The*ln best of Pharaoh’s officers are*ld drowned in the Red Sea.
The*ln deep waters have covered them; they*ld sank to the depths like a stone.
Your*ln right hand, Lord,*s was*ld majestic in power. Your*ln right hand, Lord,*s shattered*ld the enemy.
“In*pn the greatness of your majesty you*ld threw down those who opposed you. You*ln unleashed your burning anger; it*ld consumed them like stubble.
By*ln the blast of your nostrils the*ld waters piled up. The*ln surging waters stood up like a wall; the*ld deep waters congealed in the heart of the sea.
The*ln enemy boasted, ‘I*ld will pursue, I will overtake them. I*ln will divide the spoils; I*ld will gorge myself on them. I*ln will draw my sword and*ld my hand will destroy them.’
But*ln you blew with your breath, and*ld the sea covered them. They*ln sank like lead in*ld the mighty waters.
Who*ln among the gods is*ld like you, Lord?*s Who*ln is like you— majestic*ld in holiness, awesome*ln in glory, working*ld wonders?
“You*pn stretch out your right hand, and*ld the earth swallows your enemies.
In*ln your unfailing love you will lead the*ld people you have redeemed. In*ln your strength you will guide them to*ld your holy dwelling.
The*ln nations will hear and tremble; anguish*ld will grip the people of Philistia.
The*ln chiefs of Edom will be terrified, the*ld leaders of Moab will be seized with trembling, the*ln people of Canaan will melt away;
terror*ld and dread will fall on them. By*ln the power of your arm they*ld will be as still as a stone— until*ln your people pass by, Lord,*s until*ld the people you bought pass by.
You*ln will bring them in and plant them on*ld the mountain of your inheritance— the*ln place, Lord,*s you made for your dwelling, the*ld sanctuary, Lord, your hands established.
“The*pn Lord*s reigns for*ld ever and ever.”
When*p Pharaoh’s horses, chariots and horsemen went into the sea, the Lord*s brought the waters of the sea back over them, but the Israelites walked through the sea on dry ground.
Then Miriam the prophet, Aaron’s sister, took a timbrel in her hand, and all the women followed her, with timbrels and dancing.
Miriam sang to them: “Sing*pn to the Lord,*s for*ld he is highly exalted. Both*ln horse and driver he*ld has hurled into the sea.”
The Waters of Marah and Elim
Then*p Moses led Israel from the Red Sea and they went into the Desert of Shur. For three days they traveled in the desert without finding water.
When they came to Marah, they could not drink its water because it was bitter. (That is why the place is called Marah.)
So the people grumbled against Moses, saying, “What are we to drink?”

Then*p Moses cried out to the Lord,*s and the Lord*s showed him a piece of wood. He threw it into the water, and the water became fit to drink. There*p the Lord*s issued a ruling and instruction for them and put them to the test.

He said, “If you listen carefully to the Lord*s your God and do what is right in his eyes, if you pay attention to his commands and keep all his decrees, I will not bring on you any of the diseases I brought on the Egyptians, for I am the Lord,*s who heals you.”
Then*p they came to Elim, where there were twelve springs and seventy palm trees, and they camped there near the water.
